document_metadata.title: Latin Level 1 Workbook - Part 1
document_metadata.source: St John's Beaumont School Latin Students
document_metadata.subtitle: Exercises, Grammar and Vocabulary for Common Entrance Latin Level 1

thema_1.title: The Verb 'To Be'
learning_objectives: To understand 1st/2nd/3rd person and singular/plural
To translate first person singular and plural of 'to be' in Latin
To use personal pronouns ego, nos
To translate second person singular and plural of 'to be'
To translate third person singular and plural of 'to be'
To use personal pronouns tu, vos
grammar_rules: The verb 'to be' in Latin is irregular like in English
The infinitive is the part of the verb without a person
Verbs have persons: 1st (I/we), 2nd (you), 3rd (he/she/it/they)
Singular refers to one person, plural to two or more
Personal pronouns in Latin are used for emphasis
The verb 'to be' is often accompanied by a complement

thema_2.title: Intransitive Verbs
learning_objectives: To identify transitive and intransitive verbs in English and Latin
To translate Latin words in the 1st person singular and plural
To understand verb stems and thematic vowels
To form all persons (1st, 2nd, 3rd) in singular and plural
To use pronouns correctly with verbs
grammar_rules: Intransitive verbs do not need an object
Transitive verbs take a direct object
In Latin, verb endings indicate who is doing the action
1st person singular: add -o to verb stem
1st person plural: add -mus to verb stem
2nd person singular: add -s to verb stem
2nd person plural: add -tis to verb stem
3rd person singular: add -t to verb stem
3rd person plural: add -nt to verb stem
The stem for 1st conjugation verbs ends in -a-
Personal pronouns are optional but add emphasis

thema_3.title: Subjects (Nominative Case)
learning_objectives: To understand the use of the Nominative case
To learn first declension nominative singular and plural
To learn second declension nominative singular and plural
To understand second declension -er nouns
grammar_rules: Nouns belong to families called declensions
There are 5 declensions total
A noun cannot change which declension it belongs to
The nominative case is used for the subject of a sentence
The subject is the noun doing the action
1st declension nominative singular: -a
1st declension nominative plural: -ae
2nd declension nominative singular: -us
2nd declension nominative plural: -i
2nd declension -er nouns: nominative singular -er, plural -i
Most 1st declension nouns are feminine
PAIN words are masculine 1st declension: poeta, agricola, incola, nauta
If subject is plural, verb must be plural
Latin has no articles (a, an, the)

thema_4.title: Objects (Accusative Case)
learning_objectives: To recognize transitive verbs with objects in English sentences
To identify uses of the accusative case
To learn first declension accusative singular and plural
To learn second declension accusative singular and plural

key_vocabulary.note: Uses same vocabulary as previous themes, but in accusative forms

grammar_rules: Transitive verbs need an object
The accusative case is used for direct objects
The object receives the action of the verb
In Latin, word order is flexible - case endings show function
The subject is the word in nominative case, not necessarily first word
1st declension accusative singular: -am
1st declension accusative plural: -as
2nd declension accusative singular: -um
2nd declension accusative plural: -os

thema_5.title: Genders
learning_objectives: To identify feminine and masculine 1st declension nouns
To understand 2nd declension masculine nouns
To learn about 2nd declension neuter nouns
To practice using masculine, feminine and neuter nouns
grammar_rules: Latin has 3 genders: masculine, feminine, neuter
Every noun has a gender that never changes
Most 1st declension nouns are feminine
PAIN words are masculine exceptions in 1st declension
All 2nd declension -us nouns learned so far are masculine
2nd declension neuter nouns end -um in nominative singular
Gender is not always logical
When learning nouns, you must learn their gender

thema_6.title: Adjectives
learning_objectives: To understand agreement of adjectives in gender, number and case
To use nominative and accusative cases with nouns of all three genders
To learn adjectives ending in -er
grammar_rules: Adjectives must agree with nouns in 3 ways: gender, number, case
Adjectives can decline to be masculine, feminine, or neuter
Adjectives can be singular or plural
Adjectives can take any case
Some adjectives end -er in masculine nominative singular
Some -er adjectives keep the -e-, others lose it in the stem
Dictionary entries show all three genders to indicate the stem

thema_7.title: Nouns - The Genitive Case
learning_objectives: To understand possession in English using 'of' and possessive apostrophes
To use the genitive case in Latin
To learn first declension genitive singular and plural
To learn second declension genitive singular and plural
To understand the importance of genitive when learning vocabulary
To use adjectives in the genitive case

key_vocabulary.note: Uses previous vocabulary but focuses on genitive case forms

grammar_rules: The genitive case indicates possession ('of' or 's in English)
The person who owns something goes in genitive case
NOT the thing being owned
1st declension genitive singular: -ae
1st declension genitive plural: -arum
2nd declension genitive singular: -i
2nd declension genitive plural: -orum
Genitive singular ending tells you the declension and stem
1st declension: genitive ends -ae
2nd declension: genitive ends -i
Remove genitive ending to find the stem
When learning nouns, learn: nominative, genitive, gender, meaning

example_sentences.english: the farmer's spear / the spear of the farmer
the girl's water / the water of the girl

thema_8.title: First and Second Conjugations
learning_objectives: To identify 1st conjugation infinitives
To understand the thematic vowel of 1st conjugation verbs
To form 1st conjugation imperatives
To identify 2nd conjugation infinitives
To understand the thematic vowel of 2nd conjugation verbs
To form 2nd conjugation imperatives
grammar_rules: Verbs belong to families called conjugations
There are 5 conjugations total
The infinitive is the basic form of a verb
1st conjugation infinitives end -are
1st conjugation thematic vowel is -a-
2nd conjugation infinitives end -ere
2nd conjugation thematic vowel is -e-
Same person endings for both conjugations: -o, -s, -t, -mus, -tis, -nt
1st conjugation singular imperative: stem only
1st conjugation plural imperative: stem + -te
2nd conjugation imperatives follow same pattern
Thematic vowel appears before -re in infinitive

thema_9.title: Nouns - The Dative Case
learning_objectives: To understand 'to' in English
To distinguish direct objects from indirect objects
To learn 1st declension dative singular and plural
To learn 2nd declension dative singular and plural
grammar_rules: The dative case is used for indirect objects
Can be translated as 'to...' or 'for...'
Direct objects receive action directly (accusative case)
Indirect objects receive action indirectly (dative case)
1st declension dative singular: -ae (same as genitive singular)
1st declension dative plural: -is
2nd declension dative singular: -o
2nd declension dative plural: -is (same as 1st declension)
Context helps determine if -ae is nominative plural, genitive singular, or dative singular

example_sentences.english: the master gives money to the slaves
the slaves prepare food for the master

thema_10.title: Nouns - The Ablative Case
learning_objectives: To understand uses of the ablative case
To learn 1st declension ablative singular and plural
To learn 2nd declension ablative singular and plural
grammar_rules: The ablative case can be translated as 'by', 'with', or 'from'
Used for means, manner, and separation
Examples: 'by means of sword', 'with sword', 'from fear'
1st declension ablative singular: -a
1st declension ablative plural: -is (same as dative)
2nd declension ablative singular: -o (same as dative)
2nd declension ablative plural: -is (same as dative)

practice_exercises.note: Each theme includes multiple exercises with translation practice, grammar drills, and vocabulary building activities. Exercises progress from basic recognition to sentence composition.
